awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of Sound Source Localization Underlying an Ancestral Mode of Vertebrate Hearing
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to locate the source of sounds enables animals to detect prey, avoid predators and communicate with others and is thus basic to survival in many species. While decades of behavioral, physiological and neuroanatomical research have revealed the physical cues and neural mechanisms that terrestrial animals use to localize sound, the mechanisms used by fish, the oldest living vertebrate group, remain a mystery. Collectively, these experiments will investigate the mechanisms of sound localization utilized by fish that likely formed the evolutionary foundation for more recent modes of vertebrate hearing and sound localization. Throughout the project, Drs. Sisneros and Forlano will train and mentor both graduate and undergraduate students and give annual public lectures regarding the supported research at the Friday Harbor Labs (FHL). As an integral part of this research program, Drs. Sisneros and Forlano will host GK-12 teachers every summer at FHL where they will participate in field and laboratory experiments. The researchers will also develop lesson plans, student projects and an educational website with the teachers at their home institutions.   

The investigation will take an integrated behavioral, anatomical, and brain activational approach to determine whether fish are fundamentally similar to other studied vertebrates, and use binaural information (information from both ears) to localize sound, or are fundamentally different, and achieve robust localization on the basis of monaural (single-ear) information alone. The central hypothesis to be tested is that binaural integration is essential for sound source localization in midshipman. To test this hypothesis, the investigators will 1) determine which inner ear endorgans are required for sound localization behavior by testing animals in an established sound playback paradigm before and after systematic unilateral or bilateral removal of each endorgan's otolith (saccule, lagena, utricle), 2) characterize the ipsilateral and contralateral projections of inner ear afferents from all three endorgans to known auditory processing regions in the hindbrain by bulk labeling each endorgan separately or in double or triple combination with different fluorescent-labeled dextran amine tracers, and 3) characterize the brain activation patterns resulting from controlled auditory directional stimulation in intact animals and in those that have undergone systematic endorgan removal, using c-Fos as a marker for neural activation.  Duplicate digital files of all raw, processed and consolidated data will be stored locally and in the cloud by both researchers and will be made publically available within two years following publication.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this study was to determine whether fish use information from both ears (binaural cues) and what inner ear organs are used to localize underwater sound sources. Most or all vertebrates are thought to use two ears to locate sounds. Are fish similar to other vertebrates or are they fundamentally different from other vertebrates and are able to localize sound sources on the basis of single ear (monaural) information alone? The inner ear of fishes represents perhaps the earliest evolutionary design of the vertebrate auditory system that enabled these animals to locate biologically relevant sounds in complex acoustic environments. Previous work on directional hearing and sound localization by fishes suggested that both the saccule and lagena, which are thought to be the main hearing organs in fishes, and binaural input into the auditory brain were essential for sound source localization by fishes.

In this project we investigated sound source localization behavior by the plainfin midshipman fish (Porichthys notatus) by making use of the naturally occurring phonotaxis response of reproductive females to the playback of the male's advertisement call. This behavior is an unambiguous, directed swimming response by females who are ripe with eggs (ready to spawn) to pinpoint an underwater speaker that is producing the equivalent of a male?s mating call. Here we show that removing one otolith (an ear stone that is necessary for function of the organs of the inner ear) from the lagenae (left or right) or both otoliths from the saccules did not prevent sound source localization by the midshipman. Futhermore, we recorded observations in which otolith removals from all the hearing organs (the saccule, lagena and utricle) from either the left or right ear did not prevent sound source localization by midshipman. Thus, our data suggest that fish are indeed capable of sound source localization with only one inner ear intact; however, sound source localization behavior in fish only having functional audition on one side is much reduced and shows deficits in the orientation angle and swimming speed to the sound source. Our neuroanatomical studies support the behavioral data in that auditory input from different organs within one ear can provide convergent directional information to principal cells in the auditory hindbrain, which can potentially be used to determine sound source direction.

As an integral part of our research program, we have exposed a number of undergraduate and graduate students in our interdisciplinary research that is comprised of three disciplines of natural science: physics (acoustics), biology (animal behavior and communication), and neuroscience (neuroanatomy and brain physiology). Our studies have provided undergraduate and graduate training in behavior, brain histology and immunohistochemistry, fluorescent microscopy, quantitative analyses of labeled neural structures, and brain neuroanatomy. Furthermore, students at all levels were trained in science communication and many had the opportunity to present their work both informally, and at national conferences. Our research project has led to key outcomes in terms of publications in peer reviewed journals. 

Our NYC high school teacher worked to develop extensive lesson plans based on the life history, behavior and neurobiology of our model system, the plainfin midshipman fish, and we made these lessons available through our educational website. We have worked with Hudson River Park's science outreach, summer undergraduates and NYC public middle school science teachers to analyze toadfish vocalizations and anthropogenic noise in the NYC area. Our collaboration with a college-level physics instructor and another high school science teacher resulted in a published manuscript for integrating bioacoustics of midshipman vocalizations with instruction of acoustic wave principles to college and advanced high school students. We have worked with high school students each summer who have gained experience in quantitative analyses of micrographs of labeled neural structures, brain neuroanatomy and even helped developed code for automating data extraction.

We have developed a comprehensive plugin suite for ImageJ that automates and simplifies user interaction in neurohistological image analysis tasks, including region selection and thresholding, area measurement, point and object counts, and general image processing and review. This technology was accompanied by a published peer-reviewed methods paper that details the use of this plugin system and the code is freely available and hosted by the Forlano lab website.

Our project as had an impact on the physical resources (infrastructure) at the University of Washington's Friday Harbor Labs on San Juan Island, WA. As part of our project, we had two, outdoor 12ft circular concrete tanks built at FHL to perform our behavioral experiments. These tanks have also been used to hold animals for resident and visiting research scientists. In addition, these tanks are a resource for many of the summer teaching courses at the lab for holding animals for teaching purposes and for class projects.
